revision_history.draft:
# Spring, the Unbloom

The ground doesn't warm up—
it cracks open like a stomachache,
and what comes out is not green
but the purest wantonness,

a white-gooey thing that pushes through

the smallest fracture in the sidewalk,
through sewer grates, through the eye
of every nail still holding

what used to be. It doesn't stop.
It doesn't feel. It just

demolishes the parking lot into a garden
where the cars rust first—
their paint peeling back like skin,

and underneath is more skin.
The grass grows inside the tires.

There's a method to this madness,
though no one asked it:
the ruthless undermining of everything

that has learned to harden, to set,
to become the sort of thing
that resists. Watch how spring

treats concrete: it softens it
with such patience you'd swear
it was tender, was almost

apologetic—until the crack
spreads through what you thought
was final, and nothing stays

where you put it. The weed
doesn't arrive second.
It arrives the only way

anything important arrives:
by tearing open the first version

of reality and saying,
 *this will do better.*

The sprinkler head comes up anyway—
you can hear its hiss from inside
the building, that half-asleep

sound of water trying to
unmake a yard. But by the time
someone turns it off,

something has rooted in the crack

between the bricks. It doesn't care
about your plan for June.
It just keeps going—

through the blacktop, through the sewer line,
through the pipe that carries
waste and finds no waste now, finds only

ground to break apart and swallow.
This is not a gentle thing.

This is the undoing of every seal,
every caulk, every bituminous decision
to hold still. Spring doesn't give a fuck—

it just keeps pushing: root, root,
root through the septic tank,
through the house, through the

founding stone where the ledger book
used to sit and record who paid
for what, and now nothing

records because everything is

already under. The water finds
its own architecture.
The earth splits open like a wound

that doesn't scar—like a wound that
doesn't need to, since it will keep
opening, keeping

everything inside from being
still for one more day. This is not gentle.
This is the honest version:

a season with no patience for your pipes,
your mortgages, your concrete, your

belief in what you built and
how long it would last. It comes
with its own undoing—

and you can either watch

or get out of the way before

the next thing it undoes
is something you were

holding onto without realizing
you'd stopped being alive for.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The poem has a genuine engine in its central conceit: spring as entropy, destruction without malice or purpose — "no wantonness" except the wantonness of inevitability. The line "the ground cracks open like a stomachache / and what comes out is not green / but the purest wantonness" earns its place because it resists easy categorization: this violence is unpremeditated, which makes it stranger.

The image of grass growing inside tires — that's precise, surprising, and does real work. The weed arriving before anyone else, the sprinkler hissing through a closed door, the root pushing through septic pipe: these are observations with teeth. The poem knows what it wants to be in its bones.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Overcrowded imagery (abstraction and cliché risk).** The draft is already close enough that some lines are fighting for attention rather than adding layers. "White-gooey thing," "skin," "tender, was almost / apologetic" — these soften the poem's edge at exactly the moment it should be sharpening it. "A white-gooey thing that pushes through" is a sentence fragment dressed as metaphor; it reads like the poet stopped and reached for something. Direction: cut any imagery that could appear in a greeting card or home decor catalog. If you can't explain what the image does — how it *enacts* spring's indifference rather than describing that indifference — delete it.

**Sentimentality / rhetorical inflation (lines 23–40).** The poem drifts into editorializing: "it doesn't stop. / It doesn't feel." This is the poet narrating their own argument, and it weakens every line around it by making them redundant. "Watch how spring / treats concrete" — this tells us what to see instead of letting the image do its job. Direction: remove any sentence that begins with a pronoun + verb of observation ("it doesn't," "watch how"). Trust the images.

**Redundancy.** The poem says "nothing stays where you put it" and then says "everything is already under." It says "keep going" twice (lines 36–37). These are the poet restating what they've already established, which kills momentum. Direction: each image should be a new fact. If the poem returns to ground covered, that repetition must add pressure or shift meaning — right now it just stalls.

**Line breaks and form.** The line "the founding stone where the ledger book / used to sit and record who paid" is syntactically broken in a way that doesn't serve the rhythm or emphasis. It reads as a break for the sake of

revision_history.draft:
Spring, the Unbloom

The ground doesn't warm up—
it cracks open like a stomachache,
and what comes out is not green
but the purest wantonness,

a white-gooey thing that pushes through

the smallest fracture in the sidewalk,
through sewer grates, through the eye
of every nail still holding

what used to be. It doesn't stop.
It just keeps going—

through tires, through the blacktop's underside,
through the grate where rain collects,
curling upward with such determination

that nails rust first—
their heads pulling loose from concrete,
their sharpness eaten down to ferric efficiency.

The grass finds the crack between bricks.
The grass doesn't wait for permission.

Something rooted in the sprinkler head's path,

its hiss audible through walls,
half-asleep with water's own undoing—
the brass stem already softening,

already yielding its threaded logic

to the worm of expansion. Spring doesn't arrive
second; it arrives before arrival, behind

the first sealant, the caulk that thinks it's sealed,
the bitumen holding a parking lot together
so tightly even the paint peels back

like skin from skin, and underneath is more ground—
just ground, just the original pressure
ratcheting up against what was decided,

what was. The weed doesn't mind the sewer line.
The weed doesn't mind the pipe carrying waste,
finding no waste now but only

the original earth, still alive beneath concrete's
thin diplomatic veneer. This is not gentle.

This is the ground doing exactly what it always did—

and you can either watch or get out of the way
before the next thing it opens

is something you were holding onto without realizing
you'd stopped being alive for.
revision_history.critique:
## Revision Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

The core engine — spring as entropy, destruction with no malice or purpose — is genuinely alive and well in the draft. The weed pushing through a sewer grate (line 8) is precise, surprising, and does real work: it enacts the poem's thesis without editorializing about it.

"Ground cracks open like a stomachache / and what comes out is not green / but the purest wantonness," — that opening earns its place. The white-gooey line (line 5) works because it's concrete, visual, and refuses to name itself as metaphor before the reader has seen enough.

The cracked sidewalk, the root lifting asphalt like fingers pulling skin (lines 10–12), the grass growing inside bricks — these are all observation over assertion. The poem is letting images carry its weight in most places.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Sentimentality / rhetorical inflation (lines 23–40).** This is the draft's central problem, and it compounds with each line:

- **"Watch how spring / treats concrete"** — editorializing that replaces a scene.
- **"it doesn't stop. / It doesn't feel."** — two lines of summary where one image was possible.
- **"nothing stays where you put it"** — the same idea restated in line 36, and again in "everything is already under" (line 40). Repetition that stalls momentum rather than deepening meaning.
- **"a season with no patience for your pipes, / your mortgages, your concrete,"** — personification and abstraction that dilutes the poem's own hard edge. The closing three lines are almost aphorism where the rest of the draft earns its strangeness through image.

**Direction:** Cut every instance where the poet narrates what they've already shown. If "nothing stays where you put it" is in, "it doesn't stop" and "it keeps going" should go — they say the same thing with less force. The closing three lines (29–31) are the weakest cluster; rewrite or cut entirely.

**Redundancy.** Lines 28–30 ("nothing stays / where you put it / until now") repeat without progression. Direction: each image must be a new fact, or the poem loses ground.

**Cliché and abstraction.** "Skin peeling back like skin" (line 16), "tender, was almost / apologetic" — these soften into greeting-card language at the very moment the poem should sharpen its strangeness further. Direction: replace any self-referential metaphor ("skin peeling back") with a specific, observed texture.

**Line breaks and form.** "The founding stone where the ledger book / used to sit and record who paid" — the enj

revision_history.draft:
Spring, the Unbloom

The ground doesn't warm up—
it cracks open like a stomachache,
and what comes out is not green
but the purest wantonness,

a white-gooey thing that pushes through

the smallest fracture in the sidewalk,
through sewer grates, through the eye
of every nail still holding

what used to be. It doesn't stop.
It just keeps going—

through tires, through the blacktop's underside,
through the grate where rain collects,
curling upward with such determination

that nails rust first—
their heads pulling loose from concrete,
their sharpness eaten down to ferric efficiency.

The grass finds the crack between bricks.
The grass doesn't wait for permission.

Something rooted in the sprinkler head's path,

its hiss audible through walls,
half-asleep with water's own undoing—
the brass stem already softening,

already yielding its threaded logic

to the worm of expansion. Spring arrives
before arrival, behind

the first sealant, the caulk that thinks it's sealed,
the bitumen holding a parking lot together
so tightly even the paint peels back

like skin from skin, and underneath is more ground—
just ground, just the original pressure
ratcheting up against what was decided,

what was. The weed doesn't mind the sewer line.
The weed doesn't mind the pipe carrying waste,
finding no waste now but only

the original earth, still alive beneath concrete's
thin diplomatic veneer.

This is not gentle.

That is the last word.

## Workshop Response

---

### 1. What's Alive

"The ground cracks open like a stomachache / and what comes out is not green" — that opening earns its place. The white-gooey line (line 5) works because it's concrete, visual, and refuses to name itself as metaphor before the reader has seen enough.

- **"a season with no patience for your pipes, / your mortgages, your concrete,"** — personification and abstraction that dilutes the poem's own hard edge. The closing three lines are almost aphorism where the rest of the draft earns its strangeness through image.

revision_history.draft:
Spring, the Unbloom

The ground doesn't warm up—
it cracks open like a stomachache,
and what comes out is not green
but the purest wantonness,

a white-gooey thing that pushes through

the smallest fracture in the sidewalk,
through sewer grates, through the eye
of every nail still holding

what used to be. It doesn't stop.
It just keeps going—

through tires, through the blacktop's underside,
through the grate where rain collects,
curling upward with such determination

that nails rust first—
their heads pulling loose from concrete,
their sharpness eaten down to ferric efficiency.

The grass finds the crack between bricks.
The grass doesn't wait for permission.

Something rooted in the sprinkler head's path,

its hiss audible through walls,
half-asleep with water's own undoing—
the brass stem already softening,

already yielding its threaded logic

to the worm of expansion. Spring arrives
before arrival, behind

the first sealant, the caulk that thinks it's sealed,
the bitumen holding a parking lot together
so tightly even the paint peels back

like burned-on varnish from hot metal,
and underneath is just ground—
just the original pressure
ratcheting up against what was decided,

what was. The weed doesn't mind the sewer line.
The weed doesn't mind the pipe carrying waste,
finding no waste now but only

the original earth, still alive beneath concrete's
thin diplomatic veneer.

This is not gentle.

final_poem:
Spring, the Unbloom

The ground doesn't warm up—
it cracks open like a stomachache,
and what comes out is not green
but the purest wantonness,

a white-gooey thing that pushes through

the smallest fracture in the sidewalk,
through sewer grates, through the eye
of every nail still holding

what used to be. It doesn't stop.
It just keeps going—

through tires, through the blacktop's underside,
through the grate where rain collects,
curling upward with such determination

that nails rust first—
their heads pulling loose from concrete,
their sharpness eaten down to ferric efficiency.

The grass finds the crack between bricks.
The grass doesn't wait for permission.

Something rooted in the sprinkler head's path,

its hiss audible through walls,
half-asleep with water's own undoing—
the brass stem already softening,

already yielding its threaded logic

like burned-on varnish from hot metal,
and underneath is just ground—
just the original pressure
ratcheting up against what was decided,

what was. The weed doesn't mind the sewer line.
The weed doesn't mind the pipe carrying waste,
finding no waste now but only

the original earth, still alive beneath concrete's
thin diplomatic veneer.
